pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 193, 304, 209]]<|/det|>
# FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 154, 231]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 193, 907, 250]]<|/det|>
9231/11 May/June 2011 3 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 259, 470, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF10)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 321, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 366]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 367, 722, 382]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 383, 327, 398]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 399, 500, 415]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 415, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 462, 907, 493]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 493, 504, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of a calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 509, 907, 540]]<|/det|>
Results obtained solely from a graphic calculator, without supporting working or reasoning, will not receive credit.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 570, 606, 585]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 586, 756, 602]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 77, 97, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 853, 108]]<|/det|>
Express \(\frac{1}{(2r + 1)(2r + 3)}\) in partial fractions and hence use the method of differences to find

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 109, 585, 156]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{n}\frac{1}{(2r + 1)(2r + 3)}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 125, 918, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 175, 282, 194]]<|/det|>
Deduce the value of

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 193, 583, 237]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(2r + 1)(2r + 3)}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 203, 918, 222]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 271, 96, 290]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 271, 322, 290]]<|/det|>
The roots of the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 291, 584, 310]]<|/det|>
\[x^{3} + px^{2} + qx + r = 0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 316, 779, 350]]<|/det|>
are \(\frac{\beta}{k}, \beta, k\beta\), where \(p, q, r, k\) and \(\beta\) are non-zero real constants. Show that \(\beta = -\frac{q}{p}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 322, 918, 342]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 292, 381]]<|/det|>
Deduce that \(r p^{3} = q^{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 361, 918, 381]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 433, 96, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 876, 476]]<|/det|>
The linear transformation \(\mathrm{T}: \mathbb{R}^{4} \to \mathbb{R}^{4}\) is represented by the matrix \(\mathbf{M} = \left( \begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 3 & -2 & 4 \\ 5 & 15 & -9 & 19 \\ -2 & -6 & 3 & -7 \\ 3 & 9 & -5 & 11 \end{array} \right).\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 488, 316, 507]]<|/det|>
(i) Find the rank of \(\mathbf{M}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 488, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 518, 448, 537]]<|/det|>
(ii) Obtain a basis for the null space of T.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 518, 920, 537]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 565, 96, 584]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 565, 376, 584]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{f}(n) = 3^{3n} + 6^{n - 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 597, 153, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 597, 524, 616]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{f}(n + 1) + \mathrm{f}(n) = 28(3^{3n}) + 7(6^{n - 1})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 597, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 628, 153, 645]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 626, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
Hence, or otherwise, prove by mathematical induction that \(\mathrm{f}(n)\) is divisible by 7 for every positive integer \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 643, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 688, 96, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 688, 737, 707]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r = 2 \cos 2\theta\). Sketch the curve for \(0 \leqslant \theta < 2\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 689, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 720, 472, 739]]<|/det|>
Find the exact area of one loop of the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 720, 920, 739]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 766, 96, 785]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 765, 920, 833]]<|/det|>
The line \(l_{1}\) passes through the point with position vector \(8\mathbf{i} + 8\mathbf{j} - 7\mathbf{k}\) and is parallel to the vector \(4\mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j}\). The line \(l_{2}\) passes through the point with position vector \(7\mathbf{i} - 2\mathbf{j} + 4\mathbf{k}\) and is parallel to the vector \(4\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{k}\). The point \(P\) on \(l_{1}\) and the point \(Q\) on \(l_{2}\) are such that \(PQ\) is perpendicular to both \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\). In either order,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 840, 316, 858]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label> show that \(PQ = 13\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 865, 153, 883]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 864, 450, 883]]<|/det|>
find the position vectors of \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 878, 920, 897]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 601, 92]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(y\) are related by the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 100, 660, 133]]<|/det|>
\[y^{2}\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}} +2y^{2}\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} +2y\left(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\right)^{2} - 5y^{3} = 8\mathrm{e}^{-x}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 141, 344, 161]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\nu = y^{3}\), show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 163, 603, 196]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}\nu}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}} +2\frac{\mathrm{d}\nu}{\mathrm{dx}} -15\nu = 24\mathrm{e}^{-x}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 526, 92]]<|/det|>
Answer only **one** of the following two alternatives.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 106, 201, 123]]<|/det|>
# EITHER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 430, 154]]<|/det|>
Use de Moivre's theorem to prove that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 161, 598, 196]]<|/det|>
\[\tan 3\theta = \frac{3\tan\theta - \tan^3\theta}{1 - 3\tan^2\theta}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 170, 918, 189]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 217, 655, 235]]<|/det|>
State the exact values of \(\theta\), between 0 and \(\pi\), that satisfy \(\tan 3\theta = 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 217, 918, 235]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 248, 920, 282]]<|/det|>
Express each root of the equation \(t^{3} - 3t^{2} - 3t + 1 = 0\) in the form \(\tan (k\pi)\), where \(k\) is a positive rational number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 266, 920, 285]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 294, 603, 313]]<|/det|>
For each of these values of \(k\), find the exact value of \(\tan (k\pi)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 297, 920, 314]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 327, 153, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 358, 327, 375]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 375, 576, 411]]<|/det|>
\[y = \frac{x^{2} + \lambda x - 6\lambda^{2}}{x + 3},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 415, 515, 435]]<|/det|>
where \(\lambda\) is a constant such that \(\lambda \neq 1\) and \(\lambda \neq -\frac{3}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 452, 156, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 451, 732, 477]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) and deduce that if \(C\) has two stationary points then \(-\frac{3}{2} < \lambda < 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 456, 920, 475]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 490, 151, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 490, 499, 508]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 509]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 521, 153, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 521, 499, 540]]<|/det|>
Draw a sketch of \(C\) for the case \(0 < \lambda < 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 522, 920, 541]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 553, 151, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 552, 465, 571]]<|/det|>
Draw a sketch of \(C\) for the case \(\lambda > 3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 552, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
